Braskem America, Marcus Hook Polymers DE Rail Yard
Risk Management Program (RMP) Plan
Executive Summary


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
Braskem America's ("Braskem") Marcus Hook Polymers is committed to operating and maintaining our rail car storage yard in a safe and responsible manner. We have developed and implemented programs to ensure the safety of our employees, the public, and the environment, including those that satisfy Braskem's corporate standards and applicable government requirements.  Despite this area not being PSM covered, Braskem's programs satisfy or exceed all applicable requirements under both the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP). In order to ensure that our programs remain fully compliant, we periodically re-validate our Process Hazard Analyses ("PHAs") for covered processes, and choose to include the railyard in these analyses to ensure that process hazards remain properly identified, understood, and adequately mitigated.  We also utilize these PHA revalidations to identify opportunities for further safety enhancements as needed. Braskem also conducts periodic compliance audits to ensure maintenance of administrative policies and mitigation controls to help prevent accidents and releases. The facility manager retains primary responsibility for safe operation of the facility.  In addition, all employees participate in safety related teams, projects, audits, and other activities and are trained to adhere to established policies and procedures. In addition, the Marcus Hook facility has a dedicated Emergency Response Team, consisting of fully trained members.  An Emergency Response Team is available during each shift.


Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled:
This railcar storage area is located in Delaware, is a set of track space used for staging rail

cars prior to entering or exiting the facility. Braskem acts as the operator of this storage area, but does not own the track nor land. Cars are moved by a third party train operator to, from, and throughout the storage area. At no point does Braskem move railcars in this facility, and therefore does not have any full time equivalent employees on site, but does complete periodic inspections as mentioned above.

Railcars are spotted for one of the following purposes: 1) empty hopper cars awaiting non-hazardous finished product to be loaded from within the Marcus Hook Polymers facility, 2) loaded hopper cars containing non-hazardous finished product awaiting final shipment from the facility to a customer or other shipping point, 3) full LPG cars awaiting movement to the raw material unloading area of the facility to be offloaded and the material processed, or 4) empty LPG cars that have already been offloaded awaiting final return to the raw material supplier. 

The railyard may contain up to 240 total railcars, and therefore has the potential to maintain inventories of propylene and propane in quantities exceeding the 10,000 lb threshold for each constituent under the EPA RMP program. The railyard does not maintain inventories of any other material in excess of its applicable EPA RMP threshold. The facility's RMP program ensures that all constituents in the railcars, whether or not above the RMP threshold, are safely managed by confirming the railcars are maintained in accordance with applicable DOT regulations. These materials are flammable and potentially explosive if mixed with air in sufficient concentration. The facility handles these materials under pressure in both gaseous and liquid forms.


General Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
The elements of the facility's Risk Management and Process Safety Management programs are distributed among site personnel, coordinated by the Facility Manager and Lead Engineer. Facilit

y employees participate as members of PHA teams, management of change (MOC) reviews, Pre- Start Up Safety Reviews (PSSRs), incident investigations, and similar activities.  In addition, Braskem coordinates with state and local agencies in addressing PSM and RMP program considerations, including through involvement of such agency personnel in facility training activities.  

Braskem also ensures that equipment design satisfies Braskem's RMP and PSM standards.  Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or government requirements. 

In order to properly address Process Safety Information, Braskem documents relevant chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information, and ensures that such information is maintained up-to-date, and made available to operating personnel.  Braskem also conducts PHAs to identify worst case scenarios and available preventative action(s). Layers of Protection Analysis: LOPA's are conducted where warranted by the identified hazards. The protection layers identified through each LOPA are maintained to ensure continued availability of adequate protection.

Operating Procedures: Operating procedures reflect safe operating practices for each affected process.  The facility updates all operating procedures to reflect any relevant changes.

Operator Training / Certification Program: A formal training and testing program is used to ensure that operators have proper skills and knowledge prior to independently operating the process.

Technical Staff Training and Support: Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours per day to support operations. 

Maintenance Procedures: Specific procedures are developed to safely maintain applicable equipment. 

Mechanical Integrity Program: Rail cars are inspected and maintained per DOT regulations.

Management of Change: A management system is used to ensure that any modifications to affected

processes are evaluated in advance of implementation to ensure that such modifications can be safely implemented and operated.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews: Reviews are conducted just prior to start-up of affected processes to ensure safe operation.

Incident Investigation: Facility procedures provide for investigation of any accident or incident to identify cause(s) and opportunity for corrective action(s).

Employee Participation: Employees are involved in prevention program elements.

Hot Work Permit: Procedures are used to ensure that welding, cutting and brazing are safely performed in areas where flammable or combustible material may be present. 

Compliance Audits: Periodic audits and assessments are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with applicable standards.

Facility operations comply with applicable requirements of the EPA RMP rule and OSHA's PSM standard.


Five Year Accident History:
The facility has not experienced a qualified reportable release event, as described by the RMP regulations, during the five year period prior to this submission of the RMP plan.


Emergency Response Programs:
The facility maintains a written emergency response program for the site. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. In addition, the procedures address all relevant aspects of emergency response, including:
-- Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures
-- Evacuation and shelter-in-place plans 
-- Procedures to ensure that all personnel are accounted for following an incident
-- Notification procedures for local emergency response agencies
-- Post-incident cleanup and decontamination procedures, and
-- Inspection, testing, maintenance, and use of emergency response equipment.

The Marcus Hook Site maintains a trained emergency response team to respond to fires, explosions, t

oxic vapor releases, spills, and medical emergencies. The emergency response team routinely trains and conducts drills to enhance their skills and tactics for responding to any accidental chemical release. 

The facility's emergency response program provides planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed facility emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the local emergency planning committee, fire department, police department, and other appropriate agencies. These plans include:
-- Emergency Reporting through the County LEPC (911).
-- Agency reporting: National Response Center, State Emergency Operations Center.
-- Environmental Advisory Committee Reporting
-- "SARA" Hazardous Material Reporting, County and Local, State
-- Mutual Aid Agreements.
-- Drills with local Emergency Response Teams and area Company Response Teams.

The facility updates its emergency response program, as appropriate, in response to modifications to facility processes.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
Braskem is committed to continuous improvement. Programs are in place to monitor the status of ongoing efforts and continually seek opportunities to improve. For example, the facility maintains the Braskem Employee Safety Team (BEST), a multi-disciplinary team with the goal of identifying methods to continuously improve Safety. A few notable projects include the following:
--  Education of site personnel on Human Reliability philosophy to promote focus on effective solutions to problems and increased scrutiny of higher risk tasks across all work groups.
-- Education of site engineers on the facilitation of PHA's to ensure unit revalidations and projects include a detailed risk analysis.
-- Implementation of digital tools and forms to better facilitate execution, tracking, and response to operator rounds, including those in the railyard to ensure safe and reliable operation.
